content: The Rail Passenger Disaster Family Assistance Act of 2001, also known as the Short Title, provides assistance by the National Transportation Safety Board to families of passengers involved in rail passenger accidents. The Rail Passenger Disaster Family Assistance Act of 2001 amends Subchapter III of chapter 11 of title 49, United States Code, to provide assistance to families of passengers involved in rail passenger accidents by designating a director of family support services and an independent nonprofit organization. The Rail Passenger Disaster Family Assistance Act of 2001 designates an independent nonprofit organization to coordinate emotional care for families of passengers in accidents. The Board is responsible for facilitating recovery, identification of fatally injured passengers, and communicating with families about designated organizations, government agencies, and rail carriers. The designated organization for rail passenger accidents must provide mental health services, create a private grieving environment, and communicate with affected families. The designated organization for rail passenger accidents must provide mental health services, create a private grieving environment, and communicate with affected families. Periodic assistance will be provided until further deemed unnecessary, and arrangements for a memorial service will be made in consultation with the families. Passenger lists can be requested by the director of family support services for the accident. The rail passenger carrier must provide passenger lists to the designated organization for accidents upon request. The director of family support services and the organization are not allowed to release this information to anyone else. The organization must not disclose passenger information obtained from the rail carrier, but can share details with the families of passengers as deemed appropriate. The Board investigating the accident must ensure families are briefed before public announcements and have access to hearings and meetings. The organization designated for an accident must coordinate with the rail passenger carrier involved to utilize carrier resources. Prohibited actions include impeding the Board's responsibilities and restricting families' contact after an accident. No unsolicited communication regarding personal injury or wrongful death can be made by an attorney or potential party to the litigation to individuals involved in an accident before the 45th day. States cannot prevent designated organizations from providing mental health services for 30 days after the accident. In the event of a rail passenger accident, the director of family support services can extend the 30-day period for providing assistance to families by an additional 30 days if necessary. Definitions for a rail passenger accident include disasters in interstate rail passenger transportation and high-speed rail services. The term 'rail passenger carrier' refers to a rail carrier providing interstate intercity rail passenger transportation or interstate or intrastate high-speed rail transportation, excluding tourist, historic, scenic, or excursion rail carriers. The term 'passenger' includes employees of a rail passenger carrier and any other person aboard the train, regardless of payment. The term 'rail passenger carrier' refers to a rail carrier providing interstate intercity rail passenger transportation or interstate or intrastate high-speed rail transportation. In the event of a rail passenger accident, the carrier is obligated to provide assistance to passengers and their families, including those who were injured or killed in the accident. SEC. 3. RAIL PASSENGER CARRIER PLANS TO ADDRESS NEEDS OF FAMILIES OF PASSENGERS INVOLVED IN RAIL PASSENGER ACCIDENTS. Part C of subtitle V of title 49, United States Code, is amended by adding a new chapter titled "CHAPTER 251--FAMILY ASSISTANCE" which includes plans to address the needs of families of passengers involved in rail passenger accidents. Sec. 25101 requires rail passenger carriers to submit a plan within 6 months of enactment to address the needs of families involved in rail accidents resulting in major loss of life. The plan must include a toll-free number for family calls and a notification process. Rail passenger carriers must notify families of passengers before releasing names, ensure prompt notification once passenger presence is confirmed, and provide information to designated family support services. The rail passenger carrier must provide a list of passenger names upon request and update it periodically. They must also make efforts to ascertain the names of passengers on unreserved trains. Additionally, the carrier must consult with the family of each passenger regarding the handling of remains and personal effects. The rail passenger carrier must assure the return of passengers' possessions to their families upon request, retain unclaimed possessions for 18 months, and consult with families about constructing monuments for passengers killed in accidents. The rail passenger carrier must assure equal treatment for families of nonrevenue passengers, work with designated organizations for post-accident services, provide compensation to these organizations, and assist families in traveling to accident locations. Rail passenger carriers must provide assistance to families of passengers involved in accidents, including travel arrangements and physical care. They must commit resources, provide training to employees, and inform families about passenger manifests. The carrier is not liable for damages in court actions. Rail passenger carriers are not liable for damages in court actions related to passenger lists or train reservations unless gross negligence or intentional misconduct is proven. Definitions for terms like 'rail passenger accident' and 'passenger' are provided in this section. The section clarifies the actions and obligations of rail passenger carriers in providing assistance to families of passengers involved in accidents.
